Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Enforcement Officer made a reviewable error in refusing to defer removal based on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, sustained severe injuries, required ongoing psychotherapy and physical therapy, and had a pending humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Decision overturned due to patently unreasonable findings
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-compliant temporary resident with pending H&C application
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Enforcement Officer failed to properly assess medical evidence and made unreasonable factual inferences
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Medical necessity, humanitarian and compassionate considerations, risk of harm upon return to Fiji
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Availability of medical treatment in country of origin, severity of health condition, impact of removal on recovery
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision regarding deferral of removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on sufficiency and handling of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical records, psychotherapy reports, physical therapy documentation, details of pending H&C application
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for deferral of removal based on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Ongoing need for psychotherapy and physical rehabilitation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal and reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Removal orders must be executed 'as soon as reasonably practicable,' with limited discretion to consider health factors
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to properly consider available medical evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Decisional_Body: Enforcement Officer, Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB)
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of inadequate medical care and deterioration of mental and physical health if removed to Fiji
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant overstayed visa and faced deportation despite serious medical conditions and a pending H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Inadequate consideration of medical documentation by the officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly violated by applicant; issue centered on procedural fairness in enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Insufficient engagement with medical evidence by decision-maker
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of enforcement officer under IRPA to defer removal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer did not conduct meaningful assessment of medical needs
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Patently unreasonable factual findings regarding treatment prospects in Fiji
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of proper evaluation of submitted medical evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with a legally issued removal order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the enforcement officer’s decision to deny deferral of removal can be reviewed for errors in fact or law
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought deferral due to medical conditions and pending humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Decision overturned due to unreasonable factual findings and lack of proper consideration of medical evidence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Individual subject to removal order with pending H&C application
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Enforcement Officer failed to adequately assess medical evidence and made unfounded assumptions about healthcare access in Fiji
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Serious medical conditions requiring continued treatment in Canada, humanitarian concerns, pending H&C application
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Extent of medical dependency, availability of equivalent care in home country, procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging denial of deferral request
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not questioned; emphasis on completeness of evidence review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical reports, therapy records, documentation of pending H&C application
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for deferral based on health and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Need for ongoing psychotherapy and physical therapy in Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal and reassessment by a new officer
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Removal must occur 'as soon as reasonably practicable,' with limited discretion to consider health and travel factors
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of medical evidence and treatment options abroad
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential worsening of physical and mental health if returned to Fiji without adequate care
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant sought deferral of removal due to medical conditions and a pending humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Inadequate evaluation of medical documentation by the officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly violated; dispute over interpretation and application of discretion under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Failure to meaningfully engage with submitted medical evidence
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart after removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of enforcement officer’s authority under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer did not conduct thorough or reasonable assessment of medical needs
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable factual conclusions about treatment availability in Fiji and insufficient consideration of medical evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Deficient consideration of key medical evidence
